Dialogue.NPCText:
You spot a one-armed woman with sea-bright eyes and a face carved from storms, perched at the far end of The Stubborn Boar’s counter. She twirls her battered iron hook idly, grinning wide.

"Well look what the tide dragged in! Pull up a stool—Harla’s got a mug, a map, and a tale for anyone bold or bored. Don’t mind the hook; it’s only bitten three folk today. Care to swap stories, or you here to test your luck on an old pirate’s favor?"

Option.text: Heard you sailed where no honest sailor dares. Truth, or another tall tale?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Harla winks, sliding her mug aside.
"Oh, the stories are true as this storm-tossed scar." She gestures to the puckered seam on her jaw. "I sailed past Minax’s black fortress—aye, in a world that echoes this one but stinks of shadow and sorrow. Saw twisted moonlight and ships with no crew but bone and salt."

"But don’t fret. I made it back—one arm lighter, a dozen secrets heavier. Some call me liar, some call me cursed. I call myself lucky. You want proof? I’ve pieces of the old ship’s map, lost ‘round Eldermoor. Find ‘em, and maybe you’ll believe... or maybe you’ll wish you didn’t."

Option.text: If the stories are true, why stay here drinking?
Who do you trust in Eldermoor, after all you’ve seen?
Can I help you find the map pieces?
Tell me about this GloomOgre I keep hearing about.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Alone? Pah! I’ve got old Brenvar’s ale for company, Mira’s giggles behind the counter, and Aldric glaring at me like I stole his boots. Besides, half this town thinks pirates are trouble—other half just hopes I’ll buy the next round."

"Still, I’ve got one friend: the sea. Though lately, these marshes smell more like ogre sweat than saltwater. Speaking of—"

Option.text: Is the GloomOgre real, or more tavern gossip?
Heard Mira wants to leave. Do you blame her?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Harla raps her iron hook on the table, grinning.
"The ‘Storm-Crook,’ they call it. Fished from the wreck of my own ship, back in the shadowed sea—bent, battered, but handy for cracking walnuts or skulls. Lost my real hand to a sea-wraith, or so the tale goes."

"Thalen offers to smith me a new hand every winter, but I say—why cover up a badge of luck? Besides, with two hands, I’d drink twice as fast. No one needs that."

Option.text: I’d rather talk business than stories.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Her gaze grows distant.
"The ‘Sable Star.’ Fastest cutter on any world, if you believe old sailors’ yarns. She’s scattered now—some planks sunk in the shadow marsh, her heart in my chest, and a map that might open doors best left shut. Maybe you’ll find her one day, if you chase enough storms."

Option.text: Back to business. Got any work?
I’ll keep an eye out for your map.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Harla sighs, her rough voice softening.
"The sea never leaves you, not really. Mira asks why I stare at puddles when it rains—truth is, I’m waiting for the next tide to take me home. But for now? Eldermoor’s as good a harbor as any. At least until the next big storm—or the next ugly ogre—comes along."

Harla leans in, lowering her voice. Her breath smells of sea brine and strong ale.

"You want honest work or pirate work? Eldermoor’s got enough mud to bury a ship, but lately, something’s stirring out in the marsh. They call it the GloomOgre—big as a fishing sloop, foul as a privy at low tide. It’s been smashing fences, stealing livestock, and spooking every soul from Thalen’s forge to Edda’s herb garden."

"Now, most folks here talk. Me? I pay. Bring me the ogre’s club—proof you’ve dealt with the brute—and I’ll show you a piece of my old map. That, or a round of the good stuff, on me."

Option.text: What else can you tell me about the GloomOgre?
Why offer your map for an ogre’s club?
Sounds too dangerous. Maybe another time.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Harla slaps the table with her hook, startling a sleepy dog.
"That’s the spirit! Folk say the GloomOgre lairs near the willow thicket by Edda’s hut. Watch your step—he blends in with the fog and isn’t shy about throwing boulders at strangers. Bring me his club—big, ugly, and probably smells of dead fish. I’ll keep a bottle chilled for your return."

Option.text: I’ll bring you the ogre’s club.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Harla’s tone grows serious for once.
"He’s real, all right. Big, blue-skinned, eyes like lanterns in the dark. I watched him tear a tree in half just to scratch his back. Edda swears he’s ‘tainted by shadow-magic’—I just think he’s hungry. Someone’s got to put the beast down before Mira or the cattle get trampled."

"If you bring me proof—a club as tall as Thalen’s temper—I’ll reward you. Deal?"

"Old Brenvar says GloomOgre’s a ghost of the marsh, cursed by Minax herself. Edda claims the beast’s shadow is always facing east, no matter where the sun sits. Me? I reckon he just wandered in through a crack in the world. Sometimes things slip in, y’know? I would know."

Option.text: I’ll take care of him for you.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Harla’s eyes glint with mischief.
"Aye, keen for adventure, are you? My old map broke to pieces the night I sailed back through Minax’s shadow. Three scraps, last I saw: one with Mira—she took it for a keepsake; one in Aldric’s cabin, where I hid it from thieves; and one, well, the GloomOgre snatched it, mistaking it for a snack. Find all three, and you’ll see sights no sober sailor should!"

Option.text: I’ll hunt down the pieces after I deal with the ogre.

Dialogue.NPCText: "Try Mira first—she loves stories more than I do. If Aldric’s home, watch for traps—he doesn’t trust even his own shadow. As for the last piece… get ready to pry it from a GloomOgre’s molars. Don’t say I didn’t warn you!"

Option.text: Why is Mira holding your map?

Dialogue.NPCText: "Shows places that aren’t supposed to exist—a hidden port, a shadow-fortress, and paths between worlds. It’s not for the faint-hearted, and it’s inked in something that glows under moonlight. Some say following it brings fortune. Others say it brings doom. Only one way to find out, eh?"

Option.text: Let’s focus on the ogre first.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Harla rolls her eyes.
"Aldric hates pirates, simple as that. Says we bring trouble, drink too much, and steal the best stories. He’s not wrong. Still, I saved his hide in the marsh once—he hasn’t forgotten, but he’ll never thank me, either. If you see him, tell him Harla says ‘hi.’ That’ll rile him up."

"Mira’s got wanderlust worse than any pirate I ever met. I keep telling her: storms are harder than dreams. Still, I’d take her aboard, if I ever had a ship again. She’s clever, and she doesn’t judge. One of the few."

Harla smirks.
"Because stories are worth more than gold, friend. Besides, anyone brave enough to wrestle a GloomOgre deserves a taste of real adventure. And, truth be told, I’d rather see that map in your hands than rotting in a monster’s belly."

Option.text: Alright, I’ll do it for the map.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Harla’s smile grows sharper.
"All tales sound mad ‘til you see the horizon for yourself. But listen close—there’s more truth in an old pirate’s wink than most priests’ sermons. If you change your mind and crave a tale or two, you know where to find me."

"You ever lose everything in a single wave, friend? After the shadow-sea, all I wanted was dry land and folk stubborn enough to never run. Eldermoor’s just right—half mud, half grit, all heart. Maybe one day I’ll leave. Or maybe I’m just waiting for one last good adventure."

Option.text: Let’s make that adventure about killing an ogre.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Harla leans close, lowering her voice.
"Edda trusts herbs more than people. Thalen trusts his forge. Mira trusts the stars. Me? I trust folk who get their hands dirty. Help the town, and you’ll find trust comes easy—even from an old pirate."
